<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_init_page_sizes:
```c
static int metal_init_page_sizes(void)
{
	const int max_sizes = MAX_PAGE_SIZES - 1;
	long sizes[max_sizes];

	/* Determine system page size. */
	sizes[0] = getpagesize();
	if (sizes[0] <= 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to get page size\n");
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	_metal.page_size  = sizes[0];
	_metal.page_shift = metal_log2(sizes[0]);
	metal_add_page_size(_metal.tmp_path, _metal.page_shift, 0);

#ifdef HAVE_HUGETLBFS_H
#ifndef MAP_HUGE_SHIFT
	/* System does not support multiple huge page sizes. */
	sizes[0] = gethugepagesize();
	if (sizes[0] > 0) {
		metal_add_page_size(hugetlbfs_find_path(),
				    metal_log2(sizes[0]),
				    MAP_HUGETLB);
	}
#else
	if (gethugepagesize() >= 0) {
		int i, count;

		/* System supports multiple huge page sizes. */
		count = gethugepagesizes(sizes, max_sizes);
		for (i = 0; i < count; i++) {
			int shift = metal_log2(sizes[i]);

			if ((shift & MAP_HUGE_MASK) != shift)
				continue;
			metal_add_page_size(
				hugetlbfs_find_path_for_size(sizes[i]),
				shift, (MAP_HUGETLB |
				(shift << MAP_HUGE_SHIFT)));
		}
	}
#endif
#endif

	/* Finally sort the resulting array by size. */
	qsort(_metal.page_sizes, _metal.num_page_sizes,
	      sizeof(struct metal_page_size), metal_pagesize_compare);

	return 0;
}
```

explanation: Rule 8.13 concerns pointer targets that could be const-qualified. The above fragments pass path pointers (from _metal.tmp_path and from hugetlbfs_find_path*/find_path_for_size) into metal_add_page_size; these are candidates where the pointed-to string should be const if the function does not modify it. Other parts of the function do not present pointer-to-non-const issues relevant to Rule 8.13: sizes[] is intentionally writable and therefore must be non-const; getpagesize()/gethugepagesize() return integer values (not pointers); gethugepagesizes() fills the provided array (so non-const is appropriate); qsort operates on a modifiable array (base must be non-const because qsort rearranges elements), so its usage here is not a violation of making pointers const whenever possible. Logging calls and integer computations (shifts, MAP_HUGE_MASK checks) do not involve pointer-to-object const-qualification and are not relevant to Rule 8.13.
